tutorial.title: Rick and Morty - Part 2
tutorial.descriptionContent: Time to connect with the cosmos! Now, we're transitioning from local JSON to pulling real-time data via an API. Harness the power of web connectivity to fetch and showcase dynamic details from the Rick and Morty universe.

executableContent.instructions:
Welcome back to the **Rick and Morty** project. In the second part, we'll fetch the data from a server instead of creating it ourselves.

1. To transition to fetching data from the API, let's start by removing the static data object from script.js.

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rick and Morty Character Compass

files.name: style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Next, we'll use the `fetch` function to get character data from the Rick and Morty API. Fetch is a built-in function allowing us to load server data.

1. Below the definition of the variable `charactersContainer`, call the function `fetch` and pass it the URL `"https://rickandmortyapi.com/api/character"`.

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rick and Morty Character Compass

files.name: style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Once you've sent a request using fetch, it will return a response. As we want to get a JSON out of the response, we use `.json()`, which reads the response body and returns a promise that resolves with the parsed JSON content.

1. Add `.then(response => response.json())` directly after the `fetch` function.

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rick and Morty Character Compass

files.name: style.css
script.js

hints.title: What am I supposed to do?
hints.content:
This is how your code should look:

```JavaScript
fetch('https://rickandmortyapi.com/api/character')
.then(response => response.json())
```

executableContent.instructions:
After converting the `fetch` response to `JSON` format, the next step involves preparing to handle this data. We can work with the parsed data directly by chaining another `.then() `method. We'll set up the structure to handle this data in the subsequent step.

1. Add `.then(data => { });` directly after the last line of code you added.

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rick and Morty Character Compass

files.name: style.css
script.js

hints.title: What am I supposed to do?
hints.content:
This is how your code should look:

```JavaScript
fetch('https://rickandmortyapi.com/api/character')
.then(response => response.json())
.then(data => { });
```

executableContent.instructions:
With the fetched data in a usable format, loop through the results. But we don't need to code that again. We already have the code; we only need to move it.

1. Move the code where you loop over the `data` inside the last added arrow function to display the loaded data.
2. After moving the code, change `data.characters.forEach` to `data.results.forEach` as the data that the server responds uses `results` instead of `characters`.

files.content: Rick and Morty Character Compass

script.js
